1. Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a living document. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, RB Sandrini has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities.

The systems operate as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each cold room, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure accumulator. From the accumulators, low pressure liquid is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia evaporates to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator vessels. The suction gas is returned from the accumulators through a suction return line to the main suction accumulator.  From the main suction accumulator, ammonia is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water-cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to the thermosyphon vessel and then to the high pressure receiver or directly to the high pressure receiver.

The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent to the ammonia diffusion tanks if the pressure in the sys

tem exceeds their set point. 

An emergency control box is installed on free-standing structure east of the condenser on the North System and on the west exterior wall of the south refrigeration machinery room. Each box contains three valves. The high and low side of the system each have a valve that would discharge to atmosphere or the diffusion tanks. The connecting pipe between the high and low side has one equalizer valve that would equalize the system.

Each of the ammonia systems at RB Sandrini consists of vessels, valves, equipment which are interconnected by piping to form a closed-loop. The systems are neither interconnected nor co-located in respect to each other.

RAGAGEP Statement
The process equipment was inspected during the PHA for the purpose of verifying that the process was designed, fabricated, and is being operated in accordance with applicable industry standards. In the judgment of the PHA team, the North System (Process 1) was designed and installed in accordance with the 1997 UMC. This judgment was made based on the date of the nameplates (2000) and documentation provided by CalCA regarding the ventilation system design.

It is unclear which codes and standards were followed in the design and construction of the South System (Process 2). In the judgment of the PHA team, the South System most closely aligns with ANSI/IIAR 74-2 - 1978. This judgement was made because of the following:
- System lacks an ammonia diffusion tank
- Age of the facility/system (Oil Separator nameplate is dated 1985)
- Lack of documentation specifying codes and standards used at the facility

In 2017, CalCA was hired to replace the evaporators and vessels in Room 4. This project was designed and installed in accordance with ANSI/IIAR 2-2014, ANSI/IIAR 4-2015, ASME B31.5-2013, and 2015 ASME B&PV Code Section VIII Division 1


1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process

operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

RB Sandrini has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the RB Sandrini facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4 Five Year Accident History

RB Sandrini has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.
